description:
I imaged this object at the Green Bank Star Quest on my 11-inch Schmidt-Cassegrain reflector, with a much smaller field of view and much longer focal length. This image of it was taken on a 5-inch refractor, and the shorter focal length means larger FOV, which means more light concentrated per pixel, which allowed me to capture a lot more not only the inner detail, but the nebulosity surrounding the nebula.

The Crescent Nebula is the interaction of the strong stellar wind from a Wolf-Rayet star with its own ejected gas from its red giant stage a couple hundred thousand years ago. It's up in the constellation of Cygnus, the swan, which lies along the Milky Way, hence the red background nebulosity from hydrogen emission.

Blog entry link: http://astronomollylog.blogspot.com/2017/07/100-friday-july-28-2017-100th-trip.html
title: NGC 6888 Crescent Nebula #4
